code: # Data = meaudret data(meaudret) pca1 <- dudi.pca(meaudret$env, scannf = FALSE, nf = 3) bca1 <- bca(pca1, meaudret$design$site, scannf = FALSE, nf = 3) pst1 <- paste0("Meaudret BGA randtest: p=", randtest(bca1)$pvalue, " ratio=", round(bca1$ratio, 2)) xbca1 <- loocv(bca1, progress = TRUE)  if(adegraphicsLoaded()){     sc1 <- s.class(bca1$ls, meaudret$design$site, col = TRUE,     psub.text = pst1, ellipseSize=0, chullSize=1, plot = FALSE)     sc2 <- s.class(xbca1$XValCoord, meaudret$design$site,     col = TRUE, psub.text = "Meaudret cross-validation",     ellipseSize=0, chullSize=1, plot = FALSE)     ADEgS(list(sc1, sc2)) } else {   par(mfrow=c(2,2))   s.chull(dfxy = bca1$ls, fac = meaudret$design$site, cpoint = 1,        col = hcl.colors(5, "Dark 2"), sub = pst1)     s.class(bca1$ls, meaudret$design$site, col = hcl.colors(5, "Dark 2"),       cellipse = 0, add.plot = TRUE)   s.chull(dfxy = xbca1$XValCoord, fac = meaudret$design$site, cpoint = 1,        col = hcl.colors(5, "Dark 2"), sub = "Meaudret cross-validation")     s.class(xbca1$XValCoord, meaudret$design$site, col = hcl.colors(5, "Dark 2"),       cellipse = 0, add.plot = TRUE) } if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Data = rnorm() set.seed(9) fac1 <- as.factor(rep(1:3, each = 10)) tab <- as.data.frame(matrix(rnorm(10800), nrow = 30)) pca2 <- dudi.pca(tab, scannf = FALSE) bca2 <- bca(pca2, fac1, scannf = FALSE) pst2 <- paste0("rnorm spurious groups: p=", randtest(bca2)$pvalue, " ratio=", round(bca2$ratio, 2)) xbca2 <- loocv(bca2, progress = TRUE) if(adegraphicsLoaded()){   sc3 <- s.class(bca2$ls, fac1, col = TRUE,     psub.text = pst2, ellipseSize=0, chullSize=1,     xlim = c(-8, 8), ylim = c(-8, 8), plot = FALSE)   sc4 <- s.class(xbca2$XValCoord, fac1, col = TRUE,     psub.text = "rnorm cross-validation", ellipseSize=0,     chullSize=1, xlim = c(-8, 8), ylim = c(-8, 8), plot = FALSE)   ADEgS(list(sc3, sc4)) } else {   par(mfrow=c(2,2))   s.chull(bca2$ls, fac1, optchull = 1, cpoint = 1, xlim = c(-8, 8), ylim = c(-8, 8),       col = hcl.colors(3, "Dark 2"), sub = pst2)     s.class(bca2$ls, fac1, xlim = c(-8, 8), ylim = c(-8, 8),       col = hcl.colors(3, "Dark 2"), cellipse = 0, add.plot = TRUE)   s.chull(xbca2$XValCoord, fac1, optchull = 1, cpoint = 1, xlim = c(-8, 8),     ylim = c(-8, 8), col = hcl.colors(3, "Dark 2"), sub = "rnorm cross-validation")     s.class(xbca2$XValCoord, fac1, xlim = c(-8, 8), ylim = c(-8, 8),       col = hcl.colors(3, "Dark 2"), cellipse = 0, add.plot = TRUE) } } # }

title: Leave-one-out cross-validation for a discrimin analysis — loocv.discrimin
text: list :- XValCoord: cross-validated row coordinates - PRESS: Predicted Residual Error Sum row- PRESSTot: sum PRESS bca axis - Oij_disc: mean overlap index discriminant analysis- Oij_XVal: mean overlap index cross-validation- DeltaOij: spuriousness index

title: Leave-one-out cross-validation for a discrimin analysis — loocv.discrimin
text: Jean Thioulouse

title: Leave-one-out cross-validation for a discrimin analysis — loocv.discrimin
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Data = skulls data(skulls) pcaskul <- dudi.pca(skulls, scan = FALSE) facskul <- gl(5,30) diskul <- discrimin(pcaskul, facskul, scan = FALSE) xdiskul <- loocv(diskul, progress = TRUE) oijdisc <- xdiskul$Oij_disc oijxval <- xdiskul$Oij_XVal Doij <- (oijxval - oijdisc)/0.5*100 pst1 <- paste0("Skulls discrimin randtest: p=", round(randtest(diskul)$pvalue, 4),  ", Oij = ", round(oijdisc,2)) pst2 <- paste0("Skulls cross-validation: Oij = ", round(oijxval,2), ", dOij = ", round(Doij), "%") if (adegraphicsLoaded()) {   sc1 <- s.class(diskul$li, facskul, col = TRUE, psub.text = pst1, ellipseSize=0,   chullSize=1, plot = FALSE)   sc2 <- s.class(xdiskul$XValCoord, facskul, col = TRUE, psub.text = pst2,   ellipseSize=0, chullSize=1, plot = FALSE)   ADEgS(list(sc1, sc2), layout=c(2,2)) } else {   par(mfrow=c(2,2))   s.class(diskul$li, facskul, sub = pst1)   s.class(xdiskul$XValCoord, facskul, sub = pst2) } data(chazeb) pcacz <- dudi.pca(chazeb$tab, scan = FALSE) discz <- discrimin(pcacz, chazeb$cla, scan = FALSE) xdiscz <- loocv(discz, progress = TRUE) oijdiscz <- xdiscz$Oij_disc oijxvalz <- xdiscz$Oij_XVal Doijz <- (oijxvalz - oijdiscz)/0.5*100 pst1 <- paste0("Chazeb discrimin randtest: p=", round(randtest(discz)$pvalue, 4),  ", Oij = ", round(oijdiscz,2)) pst2 <- paste0("Chazeb cross-validation: Oij = ", round(oijxvalz,2), ", dOij = ",  round(Doijz), "%") if (adegraphicsLoaded()) {   tabi <- cbind(discz$li, pcacz$tab)   gr1 <- s.class(tabi, xax=1, yax=2:7, chazeb$cla, col = TRUE, plot = FALSE)   for (i in 1:6) gr1[[i]] <- update(gr1[[i]], psub.text = names(tabi)[i+1],   plot = FALSE)   pos1 <- gr1@positions   pos1[,1] <- c(0, .3333, .6667, 0, .3333, .6667)   pos1[,2] <- c(.6667, .6667, .6667, .3333, .3333, .3333)   pos1[,3] <- c(.3333, .6667, 1, .3333, .6667, 1)   pos1[,4] <- c(1, 1, 1, .6667, .6667, .6667)   gr1@positions <- pos1   sc1 <- s1d.gauss(discz$li, chazeb$cla, col = TRUE, psub.text = pst1,   plot = FALSE)   sc2 <- s1d.gauss(xdiscz$XValCoord, chazeb$cla, col = TRUE, psub.text = pst2,   plot = FALSE)   ADEgS(list(gr1[[1]], gr1[[2]], gr1[[3]], gr1[[4]], gr1[[5]], gr1[[6]], sc1, sc2)) } else {   dev.new()   sco.gauss(discz$li[,1], as.data.frame(chazeb$cla), sub = pst1)   dev.new()   sco.gauss(xdiscz$XValCoord[,1], as.data.frame(chazeb$cla), sub = pst2) } } # }

what: Assemblages of Macroinvertebrates in the Loire River (France) — macroloire
title: Assemblages of Macroinvertebrates in the Loire River (France) — macroloire
text: total 38 sites surveyed along 800 km Loire River yielding 40 species Trichoptera Coleoptera sampled riffle habitats. river divided three regions according geology: granitic highlands (Region#1), limestone lowlands (Region#2) granitic lowlands (Region#3). data set collected analyzing changes macroinvertebrate assemblages along course large river. Four criterias given : variation 1/ species composition relative abundance, 2/ taxonomic composition, 3/ Body Sizes, 4/ Feeding habits.

title: Assemblages of Macroinvertebrates in the Loire River (France) — macroloire
code: data(macroloire)

title: Assemblages of Macroinvertebrates in the Loire River (France) — macroloire
text: macroloire list 5 components. fau data frame containing abundance species station. traits data frame describes two traits : maximal sizes feeding habits species.     trait divided categories. maximal size achieved species     divided four length categories: <= 5mm ; >5-10mm ; >10-20mm ; >20-40mm.     Feeding habits comprise seven categories: engulfers, shredders, scrapers,     deposit-feeders, active filter-feeders, passive filter-feeders piercers, order.     affinity species trait category quantified using fuzzy coding approach.     score assigned species describing affinity given trait category "0"     indicates affinity "3" indicates high affinity. affinities     transformed percentage per trait per species. taxo data frame species 3 factors: Genus, Family     Order. data frame class "taxo":     variables factors giving nested classifications. envir data frame giving station, name (variable "SamplingSite"),     distance source (km, variable "Distance"), altitude (m, variable "Altitude"),     position regarding dams [1: first dam; 2:     first dam; 3: second dam] (variable "Dam"),     position one three regions defined according     geology: granitic highlands, limestone lowlands granitic     lowlands (variable "Morphoregion"), presence confluence (variable "Confluence") labels data frame containing latin names species.

title: Assemblages of Macroinvertebrates in the Loire River (France) — macroloire
text: Ivol, J.M., Guinand, B., Richoux, P. Tachet, H. (1997) Longitudinal changes     Trichoptera Coleoptera assemblages environmental conditions Loire     River (France). Archiv Hydrobiologie, 138, 525–557. Pavoine S. Doledec S. (2005) apportionment quadratic entropy:     useful alternative partitioning diversity ecological data.     Environmental Ecological Statistics, 12, 125–138.

title: Assemblages of Macroinvertebrates in the Loire River (France) — macroloire
code: data(macroloire)     apqe.Equi <- apqe(macroloire$fau, , macroloire$morphoregions)     apqe.Equi #> $call #> apqe(samples = macroloire$fau, structures = macroloire$morphoregions) #>  #> $results #>                 diversity #> Between samples 0.2701165 #> Within samples  0.5035630 #> Total           0.7736795 #>      #test.Equi <- randtest.apqe(apqe.Equi, method = "aggregated", 99)     #plot(test.Equi)      if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{       m.phy <- taxo2phylog(macroloire$taxo)     apqe.Tax <- apqe(macroloire$fau, m.phy$Wdist, macroloire$morphoregions)     apqe.Tax     #test.Tax <- randtest.apqe(apqe.Tax, method = "aggregated", 99)     #plot(test.Tax)      dSize <- sqrt(dist.prop(macroloire$traits[ ,1:4], method = 2))     apqe.Size <- apqe(macroloire$fau, dSize, macroloire$morphoregions)     apqe.Size     #test.Size <- randtest.apqe(apqe.Size, method = "aggregated", 99)     #plot(test.Size)      dFeed <- sqrt(dist.prop(macroloire$traits[ ,-(1:4)], method = 2))     apqe.Feed <- apqe(macroloire$fau, dFeed, macroloire$morphoregions)     apqe.Feed     #test.Feed <- randtest.apqe(apqe.Feed, method = "aggregated", 99)     #plot(test.Size)      } # }

code: data(mafragh) coa1 <- dudi.coa(mafragh$flo, scan = FALSE) pca1 <- dudi.pca(mafragh$xy, scan = FALSE) if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   g1 <- s.label(mafragh$xy, nb = mafragh$nb, psub.text = "Samples & Neighbourhood graph",      plot = FALSE)   g2 <- s.value(mafragh$xy, coa1$li[, 1], psub.text = "Axis 1 - COA", plot = FALSE)   g3 <- s.value(mafragh$xy, pca1$li[, 1], psub.text = "Axis 1 - PCA", plot = FALSE)   g4 <- s.class(pca1$li, mafragh$partition, psub.text = "Plane 1-2 - PCA", plot = FALSE)   g5 <- s.class(coa1$li, mafragh$partition, psub.text = "Plane 1-2 - COA", plot = FALSE)   g6 <- s.class(mafragh$xy, mafragh$partition, chullSize = 1, ellipseSize = 0, starSize = 0,      ppoints.cex = 0, plot = FALSE)   G <- ADEgS(c(g1, g2, g3, g4, g5, g6), layout = c(3, 2))  } else {   par(mfrow = c(3, 2))   s.value(mafragh$xy, coa1$li[, 1], sub = "Axis 1 - COA")   s.value(mafragh$xy, pca1$li[, 1], sub = "Axis 1 - PCA")   s.class(pca1$li, mafragh$partition, sub = "Plane 1-2 - PCA")   s.class(coa1$li, mafragh$partition, sub = "Plane 1-2 - COA")   s.chull(mafragh$xy, mafragh$partition, optchull = 1)   par(mfrow = c(1, 1)) }   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ link1 <- area2link(mafragh$area) neig1 <- neig(mat01 = 1*(link1 > 0)) nb1 <- neig2nb(neig1)  if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   if(requireNamespace("sp", quietly = TRUE)) {     g7 <- s.label(mafragh$xy, Sp = mafragh$Spatial, pSp.col = "white", plot = FALSE)     g8 <- s.label(mafragh$xy, Sp = mafragh$Spatial, pSp.col = "white", nb = nb1, plab.cex = 0,        pnb.node.cex = 0, ppoints.cex = 0, plot = FALSE)     G <- ADEgS(c(g7, g8), layout = c(2, 1))   }  } else {   par(mfrow = c(2, 1))   area.plot(mafragh$area, center = mafragh$xy, clab = 0.75)   area.plot(mafragh$area, center = mafragh$xy, graph = neig1)   par(mfrow = c(1, 1)) }  if(requireNamespace("spdep", quietly = TRUE) & requireNamespace("adespatial", quietly = TRUE)) {   lw1 <- apply(link1, 1, function(x) x[x > 0])   listw1 <- spdep::nb2listw(nb1, lw1)   coa1 <- dudi.coa(mafragh$flo, scan = FALSE, nf = 4)   ms1 <- adespatial::multispati(coa1, listw1, scan = FALSE, nfp = 2, nfn = 0)   summary(ms1)      if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {     if(requireNamespace("lattice", quietly = TRUE)) {       g9 <- s1d.barchart(coa1$eig, p1d.hori = FALSE, plot = FALSE)       g10 <- s1d.barchart(ms1$eig, p1d.hori = FALSE, plot = FALSE)       g11 <- s.corcircle(ms1$as, plot = FALSE)       g12 <- lattice::xyplot(ms1$li[, 1] ~ coa1$li[, 1])       G <- ADEgS(list(g9, g10, g11, g12), layout = c(2, 2))     }        } else {         par(mfrow = c(2, 2))     barplot(coa1$eig)     barplot(ms1$eig)     s.corcircle(ms1$as)     plot(coa1$li[, 1], ms1$li[, 1])     par(mfrow = c(1, 1))   } } } # }

code: data(maples) phy <- newick2phylog(maples$tre) dom <- maples$tab$Dom bif <- maples$tab$Bif if (requireNamespace("adephylo", quietly = TRUE) & requireNamespace("ape", quietly = TRUE)) {   phylo <- ape::read.tree(text = maples$tre)   adephylo::orthogram(dom, tre = phylo)   adephylo::orthogram(bif, tre = phylo)   par(mfrow = c(1, 2))   dotchart.phylog(phy, dom)   dotchart.phylog(phy, bif, clabel.nodes = 0.7)   par(mfrow = c(1, 1))   plot(bif, dom, pch = 20)   abline(lm(dom~bif))   summary(lm(dom~bif))   cor.test(bif, dom)   pic.bif <- ape::pic(bif, phylo)   pic.dom <- ape::pic(dom, phylo)   cor.test(pic.bif, pic.dom) }     #>  #> 	Pearson's product-moment correlation #>  #> data:  pic.bif and pic.dom #> t = -1.5823, df = 14, p-value = 0.1359 #> alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -0.7419510  0.1316186 #> sample estimates: #>        cor  #> -0.3894993  #>

what: Multiple Double Principal Coordinate Analysis — mdpcoa
title: Multiple Double Principal Coordinate Analysis — mdpcoa
text: DPCoA analysis (see dpcoa) developed Pavoine et al. (2004). used genetics describing inter-population nucleotide diversity. However, procedure can used one locus. order measure describe nucleotide diversity one locus, developed three versions multiple DPCoA using three ordination methods: multiple co-inertia analysis, STATIS, multiple factorial analysis.     multiple DPCoA allows impact various loci measurement description diversity quantified described. method general enough handle large variety data sets. complements existing methods analysis molecular variance analyses based linkage disequilibrium measures, useful study impact various loci measurement diversity.

title: Multiple Double Principal Coordinate Analysis — mdpcoa
code: mdpcoa(msamples, mdistances = NULL, method =      c("mcoa", "statis", "mfa"),      option = c("inertia", "lambda1", "uniform", "internal"),      scannf = TRUE, nf = 3, full = TRUE,      nfsep = NULL, tol = 1e-07) kplotX.mdpcoa(object, xax = 1, yax = 2, mfrow = NULL,      which.tab = 1:length(object$nX), includepop = FALSE,      clab = 0.7, cpoi = 0.7, unique.scale = FALSE,      csub = 2, possub = "bottomright") prep.mdpcoa(dnaobj, pop, model, ...)

title: Multiple Double Principal Coordinate Analysis — mdpcoa
text: msamples list data frames populations columns, alleles rows abundances entries. tables equal numbers columns (populations). table corresponds locus; mdistances list objects class 'dist', corresponding distances among alleles. order loci msamples mdistances; method One three possibilities: "mcoa", "statis", "mfa". vector given, first value considered; option One four possibilities normalizing population coordinates loci: "inertia", "lambda1", "uniform", "internal". options used MCoA MFA ; scannf logical value indicating whether eigenvalues bar plots displayed; nf scannf FALSE, integer indicating number kept axes multiple analysis; full logical value indicating whether axes kept separated analyses (one analysis, DPCoA, per locus); nfsep full FALSE, vector indicating number kept axes separated analyses; tol tolerance threshold null eigenvalues (value less tol times first one considered null); object object class 'mdpcoa'; xax number x-axis; yax number y-axis; mfrow vector form 'c(nr,nc)', otherwise computed special function 'n2mfrow'; .tab numeric vector containing numbers loci analyse; includepop logical indicating populations must displayed. case, alleles displayed points populations labels; clab character size labels; cpoi character size plotting points, used 'par("cex")'*cpoint. zero, points drawn; unique.scale TRUE, arrays figures scale; csub character size labels arrays figures used 'par("cex")*csub'; possub string characters indicating sub-title position ("topleft", "topright", "bottomleft", "bottomright"); dnaobj list dna sequences can obtained function read.dna ape package; pop factor gives name population sequence belongs; model vector giving model applied calculations distances locus. One model attributed locus, given loci alphabetical order. models can take following values: "raw", "JC69", "K80" (default), "F81", "K81", "F84", "BH87", "T92", "TN93", "GG95", "logdet", "paralin". See help documentation function "dist.dna" ape describtion models. ... ... arguments passed methods

title: Multiple Double Principal Coordinate Analysis — mdpcoa
text: functions provide following results: dist.ktab returns object class dist;

title: Multiple Double Principal Coordinate Analysis — mdpcoa
text: object obtained function mdpcoa two classes. first one "mdpcoa" second either "mcoa", "statis", "mfa", depending method chosen. Consequently, functions already available ade4 displaying graphical results can used: MCoA, - plot.mcoa: function displays (1) differences among populations according locus compromise, (2) projection principal axes individual analyses onto synthetic variables, (3) projection principal axes individual analyses onto co-inertia axes, (4) squared vectorial covariance among coinertia scores synthetic variables; - kplot.mcoa: function divides previous displays (figures 1, 2, 3 described plot.mcoa) giving one plot per locus. STATIS, - plot.statis: function displays (1) scores locus according two first eigenvectors matrix Rv, (2) scatter diagram differences among populations according compromise, (3) weight attributed locus abscissa vectorial covariance among individual analysis notations main text paper) compromise analysis ordinates, (4) covariance principal component inertia axes locus axes compromise space; - kplot.statis: function displays locus projection principal axes onto compromise space. MFA, - plot.mfa: function displays (1) differences among populations according locus compromise, (2) projection principal axes individual analyses onto compromise, (3) covariance principal component inertia axes locus axes compromise space, (4) axis compromise, amount inertia conserved projection individual analyses onto common space. - kplot.mfa: function displays locus projection principal axes populations onto compromise space.

title: Multiple Double Principal Coordinate Analysis — mdpcoa
text: Pavoine, S. Bailly, X. (2007) New analysis consistency among markers study genetic diversity:   development application description bacterial diversity. BMC Evolutionary Biology, 7, e156. Pavoine, S., Dufour, .B. Chessel, D. (2004) dissimilarities among species dissimilarities among communities:   double principal coordinate analysis. Journal Theoretical Biology, 228, 523–537.

text: Sandrine Pavoine pavoine@mnhn.fr

title: Multiple Double Principal Coordinate Analysis — mdpcoa
code: # The functions used below require the package ape data(rhizobium) if (requireNamespace("ape", quietly = TRUE)) { dat <- prep.mdpcoa(rhizobium[[1]], rhizobium[[2]],      model = c("F84", "F84", "F84", "F81"), pairwise.deletion = TRUE) sam <- dat$sam dis <- dat$dis # The distances should be Euclidean.  # Several transformations exist to render a distance object Euclidean  # (see functions cailliez, lingoes and quasieuclid in the ade4 package).  # Here we use the quasieuclid function. dis <- lapply(dis, quasieuclid) mdpcoa1 <- mdpcoa(sam, dis, scannf = FALSE, nf = 2)  # Reference analysis plot(mdpcoa1)  # Differences between the loci kplot(mdpcoa1)  # Alleles projected on the population maps. kplotX.mdpcoa(mdpcoa1) } #> Warning: Zero distance(s) #> Warning: Zero distance(s) #> Warning: Zero distance(s) #> Warning: Zero distance(s) #> Warning: Zero distance(s) #> Error in s.match(dfxy1 = mdpcoa1$Tl1, dfxy2 = as.data.frame(matrix(kronecker(c(1, 1, 1, 1), as.matrix(mdpcoa1$SynVar)), nrow = 28L, ncol = 2L,     dimnames = list(c("FTmdc.EXO.aa", "FTmlt.EXO.aa", "TELmlt.EXO.aa",     "TETmdc.EXO.aa", "TETmlt.EXO.aa", "THLmlt.EXO.aa", "THTmlt.EXO.aa",     "FTmdc.GAB.aa", "FTmlt.GAB.aa", "TELmlt.GAB.aa", "TETmdc.GAB.aa",     "TETmlt.GAB.aa", "THLmlt.GAB.aa", "THTmlt.GAB.aa", "FTmdc.NOD.aa",     "FTmlt.NOD.aa", "TELmlt.NOD.aa", "TETmdc.NOD.aa", "TETmlt.NOD.aa",     "THLmlt.NOD.aa", "THTmlt.NOD.aa", "FTmdc.RKP.aa", "FTmlt.RKP.aa",     "TELmlt.RKP.aa", "TETmdc.RKP.aa", "TETmlt.RKP.aa", "THLmlt.RKP.aa",     "THTmlt.RKP.aa"), c("Axis1", "Axis2")))), xax = 1, yax = 2,     plot = FALSE, storeData = TRUE, pos = -3, psub = list(text = "Rows"),     parrows = list(angle = 0), plabels = list(alpha = 0, boxes = list(        draw = FALSE))): non convenient selection for dfxy1 or dfxy2 (can not be converted to dataframe)

code: mfa(X, option = c("lambda1", "inertia", "uniform", "internal"),      scannf = TRUE, nf = 3) # S3 method for class 'mfa' plot(x, xax = 1, yax = 2, option.plot = 1:4, ...)  # S3 method for class 'mfa' print(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'mfa' summary(object, ...)

title: Multiple Factorial Analysis — mfa
text: X K-tables, object class ktab option string characters weighting arrays     options : lambda1 weighting group k inverse first eigenvalue k analysis inertia weighting group k inverse total inertia array k uniform uniform weighting groups internal weighting included X$tabw  scannf logical value indicating whether eigenvalues bar plot displayed nf scannf FALSE, integer indicating number kept axes x, object object class 'mfa' xax, yax numbers x-axis y-axis option.plot integer 1 4, otherwise 4 components plot displayed ... arguments passed methods

title: Multiple Factorial Analysis — mfa
text: Returns list including : tab data frame modified array rank vector ranks analyses eig numeric vector eigenvalues li data frame coordinates rows TL data frame factors associated rows (indicators table) co data frame coordinates columns TC data frame factors associated columns (indicators table) blo vector indicating number variables table lisup data frame projections normalized scores rows table link data frame containing projected inertia links arrays reference array

title: Multiple Factorial Analysis — mfa
text: Escofier, B. Pagès, J. (1994) Multiple factor analysis (AFMULT package), Computational Statistics Data Analysis, 18, 121–140.

title: Multiple Factorial Analysis — mfa
text: Daniel Chessel  Anne-Béatrice Dufour anne-beatrice.dufour@univ-lyon1.fr

title: Multiple Factorial Analysis — mfa
code: data(friday87) w1 <- data.frame(scale(friday87$fau, scal = FALSE)) w2 <- ktab.data.frame(w1, friday87$fau.blo,      tabnames = friday87$tab.names) mfa1 <- mfa(w2, scann = FALSE) mfa1 #> Multiple Factorial Analysis #> list of class mfa list of class list #> $call: mfa(X = w2, scannf = FALSE) #> $nf: 3 axis-components saved #>  #>   vector     length mode      content       #> 1 $tab.names 10     character tab names     #> 2 $blo       10     numeric   column number #> 3 $rank      1      numeric   tab rank      #> 4 $eig       15     numeric   eigen values  #> 5 $lw        16     numeric   row weights   #> 6 $tabw      0      NULL      array weights #>  #>    data.frame nrow ncol content                         #> 1  $tab       16   91   modified array                  #> 2  $li        16   3    row coordinates                 #> 3  $l1        16   3    row normed scores               #> 4  $co        91   3    column coordinates              #> 5  $c1        91   3    column normed scores            #> 6  $lisup     160  3    row coordinates from each table #> 7  $TL        160  2    factors for li l1               #> 8  $TC        91   2    factors for co c1               #> 9  $T4        40   2    factors for T4comp              #> 10 $T4comp    40   3    component projection            #> 11 $link      10   3    link array-total                #> other elements: NULL plot(mfa1) #> Error in eval(thecall$fac, envir = sys.frame(sys.nframe() + pos)): object 'mfa1' not found  data(escopage) w <- data.frame(scale(escopage$tab)) w <- ktab.data.frame(w, escopage$blo, tabnames = escopage$tab.names) plot(mfa(w, scann = FALSE)) #> Error in eval(thecall$fac, envir = sys.frame(sys.nframe() + pos)): object 'w' not found

title: Phylogeny and quantitative traits of teleos fishes — mjrochet
code: data(mjrochet) mjrochet.phy <- newick2phylog(mjrochet$tre) tab <- log((mjrochet$tab)) tab0 <- data.frame(scalewt(tab)) table.phylog(tab0, mjrochet.phy, csi = 2, clabel.r = 0.75)  if (requireNamespace("adephylo", quietly = TRUE)) {   adephylo::orthogram(tab0[,1], ortho = mjrochet.phy$Bscores) }  #> class: krandtest lightkrandtest  #> Monte-Carlo tests #> Call: adephylo::orthogram(x = tab0[, 1], orthobas = mjrochet.phy$Bscores) #>  #> Number of tests:   4  #>  #> Adjustment method for multiple comparisons:   none  #> Permutation number:   999  #>    Test        Obs   Std.Obs   Alter Pvalue #> 1 R2Max  0.1501481  1.065401 greater  0.132 #> 2 SkR2k 14.7098590 -3.577331 greater  1.000 #> 3  Dmax  0.3519553  3.845578 greater  0.001 #> 4   SCE  2.5268895  8.633494 greater  0.001 #>

what: Multi Level Decomposition of unidimensional data — mld
title: Multi Level Decomposition of unidimensional data — mld
text: function mld performs additive decomposition input vector x onto sub-spaces associated orthonormal orthobasis. sub-spaces defined levels input factor level. function haar2level builds factor level multi level decomposition corresponds exactly multiresolution analysis performed haar basis.

title: Multi Level Decomposition of unidimensional data — mld
code: mld(x, orthobas, level, na.action = c("fail", "mean"),  plot = TRUE, dfxy = NULL, phylog = NULL, ...) haar2level(x)

title: Multi Level Decomposition of unidimensional data — mld
text: x vector time serie containing data decomposed. must dyadic length vector (power 2) function haar2level. orthobas data frame containing vectors orthonormal basis. level factor levels define sub-spaces function mld performs additive decomposition. na.action 'fail' stops execution current expression x contains missing value. 'mean' replaces missing values mean(x). plot TRUE plot x components resulting decomposition. dfxy data frame two coordinates. phylog object class phylog. ... arguments passed methods.

title: Multi Level Decomposition of unidimensional data — mld
text: data frame components resulting decomposition.

title: Multi Level Decomposition of unidimensional data — mld
text: Mallat, S. G. (1989) theory multiresolution signal decomposition: wavelet representation. IEEE Transactions Pattern Analysis Machine Intelligence, 11, 7, 674–693. Percival, D. B. Walden, . T. (2000) Wavelet Methods Time Series Analysis, Cambridge University Press.

title: Multi Level Decomposition of unidimensional data — mld
text: Sébastien Ollier sebastien.ollier@u-psud.fr

title: Multi Level Decomposition of unidimensional data — mld
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # decomposition of a time serie data(co2) x <- log(co2) orthobas <- orthobasis.line(length(x)) level<-rep("D", 467) level[1:3]<-rep("A", 3) level[c(77,78,79,81)]<-rep("B", 4) level[156]<-"C" level<-as.factor(level) res <- mld(x, orthobas, level) sum(scale(x, scale = FALSE) - apply(res, 1, sum)) } # } # decomposition of a biological trait on a phylogeny data(palm) vfruit<-palm$traits$vfruit vfruit<-scalewt(vfruit)    palm.phy<-newick2phylog(palm$tre) level <- rep("F", 65) level[c(4, 21, 3, 6, 13)] <- LETTERS[1:5] level <- as.factor(level) res <- mld(as.vector(vfruit), palm.phy$Bscores, level,  phylog = palm.phy, clabel.nod = 0.7, f.phylog=0.8,   csize = 2, clabel.row = 0.7, clabel.col = 0.7)

code: data(mollusc) coa1 <- dudi.coa(log(mollusc$fau + 1), scannf = FALSE, nf = 3)  if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   g1 <- s.class(coa1$li, mollusc$plan$site, ellipseSize = 0, starSize = 0, chullSize = 1,      xax = 2, yax = 3, plot = FALSE)   g2 <- s.class(coa1$li, mollusc$plan$season, ellipseSize = 0, starSize = 0, chullSize = 1,      xax = 2, yax = 3, plot = FALSE)   g3 <- s.class(coa1$li, mollusc$plan$method, ellipseSize = 0, starSize = 0, chullSize = 1,      xax = 2, yax = 3, plot = FALSE)   g4 <- s.class(coa1$li, mollusc$plan$duration, ellipseSize = 0, starSize = 0, chullSize = 1,      xax = 2, yax = 3, plot = FALSE)   G <- ADEgS(list(g1, g2, g3, g4), layout = c(2, 2))    } else {   par(mfrow = c(2, 2))   s.chull(coa1$li, mollusc$plan$site, 2, 3, opt = 1, cpoi = 1)   s.chull(coa1$li, mollusc$plan$season, 2, 3, opt = 1, cpoi = 1)   s.chull(coa1$li, mollusc$plan$method, 2, 3, opt = 1, cpoi = 1)   s.chull(coa1$li, mollusc$plan$duration, 2, 3, opt = 1, cpoi = 1)   par(mfrow = c(1, 1)) }

title: Minimal Spanning Tree — mstree
text: Daniel Chessel

title: Minimal Spanning Tree — mstree
code: data(mafragh) maf.coa <- dudi.coa(mafragh$flo, scan = FALSE) maf.mst <- ade4::mstree(dist.dudi(maf.coa), 1)  if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   g0 <- s.label(maf.coa$li, plab.cex = 0, ppoints.cex = 2, nb = neig2nb(maf.mst)) } else {   s.label(maf.coa$li, clab = 0, cpoi = 2, neig = maf.mst, cnei = 1) }   xy <- data.frame(x = runif(20), y = runif(20))  if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   g1 <- s.label(xy, xlim = c(0, 1), ylim = c(0, 1),      nb = neig2nb(ade4::mstree(dist.quant(xy, 1), 1)), plot = FALSE)   g2 <- s.label(xy, xlim = c(0, 1), ylim = c(0, 1),      nb = neig2nb(ade4::mstree(dist.quant(xy, 1), 2)), plot = FALSE)   g3 <- s.label(xy, xlim = c(0, 1), ylim = c(0, 1),      nb = neig2nb(ade4::mstree(dist.quant(xy, 1), 3)), plot = FALSE)   g4 <- s.label(xy, xlim = c(0, 1), ylim = c(0, 1),      nb = neig2nb(ade4::mstree(dist.quant(xy, 1), 4)), plot = FALSE)   G <- ADEgS(list(g1, g2, g3, g4), layout = c(2, 2))  } else {   par(mfrow = c(2, 2))   for(k in 1:4) {     neig <- mstree(dist.quant(xy, 1), k)     s.label(xy, xlim = c(0, 1), ylim = c(0, 1), addax = FALSE, neig = neig)   } }

title: Neighbourhood Graphs — neig
text: neig creates objects class neig :      list edges     binary square matrix     list vectors neighbours     integer (linear circular graphs)     data frame polygons (area) scores.neig returns eigenvectors neighbouring, orthonormalized scores (null average, unit variance 1/n null covariances) maximal autocorrelation. nb2neig returns object class neig using object class nb library 'spdep' neig2nb returns object class nb using object class neig neig2mat returns incidence matrix edges (1 = neighbour ; 0 = neighbour) neig.util.GtoL neig.util.LtoG utilities.

title: Neighbourhood Graphs — neig
code: neig(list = NULL, mat01 = NULL, edges = NULL,     n.line = NULL, n.circle = NULL, area = NULL)  scores.neig  (obj)  # S3 method for class 'neig' print(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'neig' summary(object, ...) nb2neig (nb) neig2nb (neig) neig2mat (neig)

title: Neighbourhood Graphs — neig
text: list list component gives number neighbours mat01 symmetric square matrix 0-1 values edges matrix 2 columns integer values giving list edges n.line number points linear plot n.circle number points circular plot area data frame containing polygon set (see area.plot) nb object class 'nb' neig, x, obj, object object class 'neig' ... arguments passed methods

title: Neighbourhood Graphs — neig
code: if(!adegraphicsLoaded()) {      if(requireNamespace("deldir", quietly = TRUE)) {        data(mafragh)     par(mfrow = c(2, 1))     provi <- deldir::deldir(mafragh$xy)     provi.neig <- neig(edges = as.matrix(provi$delsgs[, 5:6]))          s.label(mafragh$xy, neig = provi.neig, inc = FALSE,        addax = FALSE, clab = 0, cnei = 2)     dist <- apply(provi.neig, 1, function(x)        sqrt(sum((mafragh$xy[x[1], ] - mafragh$xy[x[2], ]) ^ 2)))     #hist(dist, nclass = 50)     mafragh.neig <- neig(edges = provi.neig[dist < 50, ])     s.label(mafragh$xy, neig = mafragh.neig, inc = FALSE,        addax = FALSE, clab = 0, cnei = 2)     par(mfrow = c(1, 1))          data(irishdata)     irish.neig <- neig(area = irishdata$area)     summary(irish.neig)     print(irish.neig)     s.label(irishdata$xy, neig = irish.neig, cneig = 3,       area = irishdata$area, clab = 0.8, inc = FALSE)          irish.scores <- scores.neig(irish.neig)     par(mfrow = c(2, 3))     for(i in 1:6)       s.value(irishdata$xy, irish.scores[, i], inc = FALSE, grid = FALSE, addax = FALSE,         neig = irish.neig, csi = 2, cleg = 0, sub = paste("Eigenvector ",i), csub = 2)     par(mfrow = c(1, 1))          a.neig <- neig(n.circle = 16)     a.scores <- scores.neig(a.neig)     xy <- cbind.data.frame(cos((1:16) * pi / 8), sin((1:16) * pi / 8))     par(mfrow = c(4, 4))     for(i in 1:15)       s.value(xy, a.scores[, i], neig = a.neig, csi = 3, cleg = 0)     par(mfrow = c(1, 1))          a.neig <- neig(n.line = 28)     a.scores <- scores.neig(a.neig)     par(mfrow = c(7, 4))     par(mar = c(1.1, 2.1, 0.1, 0.1))     for(i in 1:27)       barplot(a.scores[, i], col = grey(0.8))     par(mfrow = c(1, 1))   }    if(requireNamespace("spdep", quietly = TRUE)) {          data(mafragh)     maf.rel <- spdep::relativeneigh(as.matrix(mafragh$xy))     maf.rel <- spdep::graph2nb(maf.rel)     s.label(mafragh$xy, neig = neig(list = maf.rel), inc = FALSE,       clab = 0, addax = FALSE, cne = 1, cpo = 2)          par(mfrow = c(2, 2))     w <- matrix(runif(100), 50, 2)     x.gab <- spdep::gabrielneigh(w)     x.gab <- spdep::graph2nb(x.gab)     s.label(data.frame(w), neig = neig(list = x.gab), inc = FALSE,       clab = 0, addax = FALSE, cne = 1, cpo = 2, sub = "relative")     x.rel <- spdep::relativeneigh(w)     x.rel <- spdep::graph2nb(x.rel)     s.label(data.frame(w), neig = neig(list = x.rel), inc = FALSE,       clab = 0, addax = FALSE, cne = 1, cpo = 2, sub = "Gabriel")     k1 <- spdep::knn2nb(spdep::knearneigh(w))     s.label(data.frame(w), neig = neig(list = k1), inc = FALSE,       clab = 0, addax = FALSE, cne = 1, cpo = 2, sub = "k nearest neighbours")          all.linked <- max(unlist(spdep::nbdists(k1, w)))     z <- spdep::dnearneigh(w, 0, all.linked)     s.label(data.frame(w), neig = neig(list = z), inc = FALSE, clab = 0,        addax = FALSE, cne = 1, cpo = 2, sub = "Neighbourhood contiguity by distance")     par(mfrow = c(1, 1))   }    }  #> title: Phylogenetic trees in Newick format — newick.eg
code: data(newick.eg) newick2phylog(newick.eg[[11]]) #> Phylogenetic tree with 18 leaves and 17 nodes #> $class: phylog #> $call: newick2phylog(x.tre = newick.eg[[11]]) #> $tre: ((Sa,Sh)I1,((((Tl,(Mc,My)...Ls,Lv)I13)I14)I15)I16)Root;  #>  #>         class   length content                                      #> $leaves numeric 18     length of the first preceeding adjacent edge #> $nodes  numeric 17     length of the first preceeding adjacent edge #> $parts  list    17     subsets of descendant nodes                  #> $paths  list    35     path from root to node or leave              #> $droot  numeric 35     distance to root                             #>  #>          class      dim   content                                    #> $Wmat    matrix     18-18 W matrix : root to the closest ancestor    #> $Wdist   dist       153   Nodal distances                            #> $Wvalues numeric    17    Eigen values of QWQ/sum(Q)                 #> $Wscores data.frame 18-17 Eigen vectors of QWQ '1/n' normed          #> $Amat    matrix     18-18 Topological proximity matrix A             #> $Avalues numeric    17    Eigen values of QAQ matrix                 #> $Adim    integer    1     number of positive eigen values of QAQ     #> $Ascores data.frame 18-17 Eigen vectors of QAQ '1/n' normed          #> $Aparam  data.frame 17-3  Topological indices for nodes              #> $Bindica data.frame 18-17 class indicator from nodes                 #> $Bscores data.frame 18-17 Topological orthonormal basis '1/n' normed #> $Blabels character  17    Nodes labelling from orthonormal basis     radial.phylog(newick2phylog(newick.eg[[7]]), circ = 1,  clabel.l = 0.75)

title: Create phylogeny — newick2phylog
text: first three functions ensure create object class phylog either character string Newick format (newick2phylog) object class 'hclust' (hclust2phylog) taxonomy (taxo2phylog). function newick2phylog.addtools internal function called newick2phylog, hclust2phylog taxo2phylog newick2phylog.addtools = TRUE. adds items 'phylog' objects.

title: Create phylogeny — newick2phylog
code: newick2phylog(x.tre, add.tools = TRUE, call = match.call()) hclust2phylog(hc, add.tools = TRUE) taxo2phylog(taxo, add.tools = FALSE, root="Root", abbrev=TRUE) newick2phylog.addtools(res, tol = 1e-07)

title: Create phylogeny — newick2phylog
text: x.tre character string corresponding phylogenetic tree Newick format    (see phylip software) add.tools TRUE, executes function newick2phylog.addtools call call hc object class hclust taxo object class taxo res object class phylog (internal argument function newick2phylog) tol used case 3 method tolerance threshold null eigenvalues root character string root tree abbrev logical : TRUE levels abbreviated column two characters added

title: Create phylogeny — newick2phylog
text: Return object class phylog.

title: Create phylogeny — newick2phylog
code: w <- "((((,,),,(,)),),(,));"  w.phy <- newick2phylog(w)  print(w.phy) #> Phylogenetic tree with 9 leaves and 6 nodes #> $class: phylog #> $call: newick2phylog(x.tre = w) #> $tre: ((((Ext1,Ext2,Ext3)I1,Ext...Ext7)I4,(Ext8,Ext9)I5)Root;  #>  #>         class   length content                                      #> $leaves numeric 9      length of the first preceeding adjacent edge #> $nodes  numeric 6      length of the first preceeding adjacent edge #> $parts  list    6      subsets of descendant nodes                  #> $paths  list    15     path from root to node or leave              #> $droot  numeric 15     distance to root                             #>  #>          class      dim content                                    #> $Wmat    matrix     9-9 W matrix : root to the closest ancestor    #> $Wdist   dist       36  Nodal distances                            #> $Wvalues numeric    8   Eigen values of QWQ/sum(Q)                 #> $Wscores data.frame 9-8 Eigen vectors of QWQ '1/n' normed          #> $Amat    matrix     9-9 Topological proximity matrix A             #> $Avalues numeric    8   Eigen values of QAQ matrix                 #> $Adim    integer    1   number of positive eigen values of QAQ     #> $Ascores data.frame 9-8 Eigen vectors of QAQ '1/n' normed          #> $Aparam  data.frame 6-3 Topological indices for nodes              #> $Bindica data.frame 9-8 class indicator from nodes                 #> $Bscores data.frame 9-8 Topological orthonormal basis '1/n' normed #> $Blabels character  6   Nodes labelling from orthonormal basis      plot(w.phy)   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # newick2phylog data(newick.eg) radial.phylog(newick2phylog(newick.eg[[8]], FALSE), cnode = 1,  clabel.l = 0.8)  w <- NULL w[1] <- "(,((((((((((((((((,,(,(,))),),(((,(,)),(,)),),(,(,)),(,)),(((((" w[2] <- ",(,)),),),(,)),((((,((,),((,(,)),))),(,)),(,(,),,((,),(,)),)),(" w[3] <- "(((((,),),(,(,))),),(,)),(((,),),)))),((,,((,),)),(,)),((,),(,)" w[4] <- ")),(((((((((,,),),,),),((,),)),(,),((,),)),),(((((,),),),((,),)" w[5] <- "),(((,(,(,(,)))),(,)),(((,),(((((((,),),),,),(,)),(,)),)),((,)" w[6] <- ",))))),(,((,),(,)),((,(,)),)))),((((,(,(,))),((,(,)),,((,(,)),)" w[7] <- ",)),(((,),),(((,),),))),((,),))),((((((((((,,,,(,)),),((,),)),(" w[8] <- ",(,))),(((((((((,(,)),(,)),((((,((,),(,(,(,))))),((,),(,(,))))," w[9] <- "),((,),))),(((((((((,(,)),((,),(,))),),),),(((,((,),)),),((,((," w[10] <- "),)),)),(,)),(,(,(,)))),((((,(,)),(,)),(((,),(,)),(,),,(,))),(," w[11] <- "))),(,,,))),((((,),),),(((,(,(,))),((,),)),(,)))),(,)),),(,((,(" w[12] <- ",)),),(((,),),))),),(((,),),(,),(,(,))),(((,),(,)),((,),(,))))," w[13] <- "(((,),((,),)),(((((,,,,,),(,)),(,)),(,((,),))),))),(,(((((,((((" w[14] <- ",(,)),),),)),),((,((,),((,((,),(,))),))),)),((((,),(((,),(,(,))" w[15] <- "),)),),)),((,),)))),(((,((,,((,),)),)),),((,),))),((,),(,))),((" w[16] <- ",),)),(((((,),((,(,)),(((,(,)),(,(((,),),))),))),(,),,),),),,(," w[17] <- ")),((((,),,),),((,,,),((,),((,),))))),((((((,(,)),,(,)),,(,),(," w[18] <- "),),(((((,(,(,),)),(((,),,),(,))),),),),,,((,),)),),)),(((((,)," w[19] <- "(,(,)),),((,((,),),,),)),(((((((,),((((,,,),(,(,))),(((,(,)),)," w[20] <- "(,))),)),),),),(,)),),),((,),))),((,),)),(((((((((((,),),((((((" w[21] <- ",),),((,),)),(,)),),)),(,)),),((((((,),),(((,),),)),(,)),),(,))" w[22] <- ",),),),),(,)),),((,),(,),,,)),(,(,(,)))),),(,)),),);" phy1 <- newick2phylog(w,FALSE) phy1 radial.phylog(phy1, clabel.l = 0, circle = 2.2, clea = 0.5,  cnod = 0.5) data(newick.eg) radial.phylog(newick2phylog(newick.eg[[8]], FALSE), cnode = 1,  clabel.l = 0.8)  # hclust2phylog data(USArrests) hc <- hclust(dist(USArrests), "ave") par(mfrow = c(1,2)) plot(hc, hang = -1) phy <- hclust2phylog(hc) plot(phy, clabel.l = 0.75, clabel.n = 0.6, f = 0.75)  par(mfrow = c(1,1)) row.names(USArrests)  names(phy$leaves) #WARNING not the same for two reasons row.names(USArrests) <- gsub(" ","_",row.names(USArrests)) row.names(USArrests)  names(phy$leaves) #WARNING not the same for one reason USArrests <- USArrests[names(phy$leaves),] row.names(USArrests)  names(phy$leaves) #the same table.phylog(data.frame(scalewt(USArrests)), phy, csi = 2.5,  clabel.r = 0.75, f = 0.7)  #taxo2phylog data(taxo.eg) tax <- as.taxo(taxo.eg[[1]]) tax.phy <- taxo2phylog(as.taxo(taxo.eg[[1]])) par(mfrow = c(1,2)) plot(tax.phy, clabel.l = 1.25, clabel.n = 1.25, f = 0.75) plot(taxo2phylog(as.taxo(taxo.eg[[1]][sample(15),])),  clabel.l = 1.25, clabel.n = 1.25, f = 0.75)  par(mfrow=c(1,1)) plot(taxo2phylog(as.taxo(taxo.eg[[2]])), clabel.l = 1,  clabel.n = 0.75, f = 0.65) } # }

title: Method to Analyse a pair of tables : Environmental and Faunistic Data — niche
text: dudiX duality diagram providing function dudi.coa, dudi.pca, ... using array sites-variables Y data frame sites-species according dudiX$tab columns zero scannf logical value indicating whether eigenvalues bar plot displayed nf scannf FALSE, integer indicating number kept axes x object class niche ... arguments passed methods xax, yax numbers x-axis y-axis xtest object class niche nrepet number permutations testing procedure

title: Method to Analyse a pair of tables : Environmental and Faunistic Data — niche
text: Returns list class niche (sub-class dudi) containing : rank integer indicating rank studied matrix nf integer indicating number kept axes RV numeric value indicating RV coefficient eig numeric vector eigenvalues lw data frame row weigths (crossed array) tab data frame crossed array (averaging species/sites) li data frame species coordinates l1 data frame species normed scores co data frame variable coordinates c1 data frame variable normed scores ls data frame site coordinates data frame axis upon niche axis

title: Method to Analyse a pair of tables : Environmental and Faunistic Data — niche
text: Daniel Chessel Anne-Béatrice Dufour anne-beatrice.dufour@univ-lyon1.fr Stéphane Dray stephane.dray@univ-lyon1.fr

title: Method to Analyse a pair of tables : Environmental and Faunistic Data — niche
code: data(doubs) dudi1 <- dudi.pca(doubs$env, scale = TRUE, scan = FALSE, nf = 3) nic1 <- niche(dudi1, doubs$fish, scann = FALSE)  if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   g1 <- s.traject(dudi1$li, plab.cex = 0, plot = FALSE)   g2 <- s.traject(nic1$ls, plab.cex = 0, plot = FALSE)   g3 <- s.corcircle(nic1$as, plot = FALSE)   g4 <- s.arrow(nic1$c1, plot = FALSE)   G1 <- ADEgS(list(g1, g2, g3, g4), layout = c(2, 2))      glist <- list()   for(i in 1:ncol(doubs$fish))     glist[[i]] <- s.distri(nic1$ls, dfdistri = doubs$fish[, i], psub.text = names(doubs$fish)[i],        plot = FALSE, storeData = TRUE)   G2 <- ADEgS(glist, layout = c(5, 6))      G3 <- s.arrow(nic1$li, plab.cex = 0.7)        } else {   par(mfrow = c(2, 2))   s.traject(dudi1$li, clab = 0)   s.traject(nic1$ls, clab = 0)   s.corcircle(nic1$as)   s.arrow(nic1$c1)    par(mfrow = c(5, 6))   for (i in 1:27) s.distri(nic1$ls, as.data.frame(doubs$fish[,i]),     csub = 2, sub = names(doubs$fish)[i])        par(mfrow = c(1, 1))   s.arrow(nic1$li, clab = 0.7)  }     data(trichometeo) pca1 <- dudi.pca(trichometeo$meteo, scan = FALSE) nic1 <- niche(pca1, log(trichometeo$fau + 1), scan = FALSE) plot(nic1) #> Error in s.corcircle(dfxy = nic1$as, xax = 1, yax = 2, plot = FALSE, storeData = TRUE,     pos = -3, psub = list(text = "Unconstrained axes"), pbackground = list(        box = FALSE), plabels = list(cex = 1.25)): non convenient selection for dfxy (can not be converted to dataframe) niche.param(nic1) #>       inertia         OMI       Tol     Rtol  omi  tol rtol #> Che  6.433882  2.77316816 1.0214504 2.639263 43.1 15.9 41.0 #> Hyc title: Non-linear Iterative Partial Least Squares (NIPALS) algorithm — nipals
text: df data frame can contain missing values nf integer, number axes keep rec logical specify functions must perform     reconstitution data using nf axes niter integer, maximum number iterations tol real, tolerance used iterative algorithm x object class nipals xax column number x-axis yax column number y-axis clab.row character size rows clab.col character size columns posieig "top" eigenvalues bar plot upside, "bottom" downside, "none" plot sub string characters inserted legend ... arguments passed methods

title: Non-linear Iterative Partial Least Squares (NIPALS) algorithm — nipals
text: Stéphane Dray stephane.dray@univ-lyon1.fr

title: Non-linear Iterative Partial Least Squares (NIPALS) algorithm — nipals
code: data(doubs) ## nipals is equivalent to dudi.pca when there are no NA acp1 <- dudi.pca(doubs$env, scannf = FALSE, nf = 2) nip1 <- nipals(doubs$env)   if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   if(requireNamespace("lattice", quietly = TRUE)) {     g1 <- s1d.barchart(acp1$eig, psub.text = "dudi.pca", p1d.horizontal = FALSE, plot = FALSE)     g2 <- s1d.barchart(nip1$eig, psub.text = "nipals", p1d.horizontal = FALSE, plot = FALSE)     g3 <- lattice::xyplot(nip1$c1[, 1] ~ acp1$c1[, 1], main = "col scores", xlab = "dudi.pca",        ylab = "nipals")     g4 <- lattice::xyplot(nip1$li[, 1] ~ acp1$li[, 1], main = "row scores", xlab = "dudi.pca",        ylab = "nipals")     G <- ADEgS(list(g1, g2, g3, g4), layout = c(2, 2))   }    } else {   par(mfrow = c(2, 2))   barplot(acp1$eig, main = "dudi.pca")   barplot(nip1$eig, main = "nipals")   plot(acp1$c1[, 1], nip1$c1[, 1], main = "col scores", xlab = "dudi.pca", ylab = "nipals")   plot(acp1$li[, 1], nip1$li[, 1], main = "row scores", xlab = "dudi.pca", ylab = "nipals") }   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ ## with NAs: doubs$env[1, 1] <- NA nip2 <- nipals(doubs$env) cor(nip1$li, nip2$li) nip1$eig nip2$eig } # }

code: data(olympic) pca1 <- dudi.pca(olympic$tab, scan = FALSE)  if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   if(requireNamespace("lattice", quietly = TRUE)) {     g1 <- s1d.barchart(pca1$eig, p1d.hori = FALSE, plot = FALSE)     g2 <- s.corcircle(pca1$co, plot = FALSE)     g3 <- lattice::xyplot(pca1$l1[, 1] ~ olympic$score, type = c("p", "r"))     g41 <- s.label(pca1$l1, plab.cex = 0.5, plot = FALSE)     g42 <- s.arrow(2 * pca1$co, plot = FALSE)     g4 <- superpose(g41, g42)     G <- ADEgS(list(g1, g2, g3, g4), layout = c(2, 2))   }    } else {   par(mfrow = c(2, 2))   barplot(pca1$eig)   s.corcircle(pca1$co)   plot(olympic$score, pca1$l1[, 1])   abline(lm(pca1$l1[, 1] ~ olympic$score))   s.label(pca1$l1, clab = 0.5)   s.arrow(2 * pca1$co, add.p = TRUE)   par(mfrow = c(1, 1)) }

what: Orthonormal basis for orthonormal transform — orthobasis
title: Orthonormal basis for orthonormal transform — orthobasis
text: functions returns object class 'orthobasis' contains data frame defining orthonormal basis. orthobasic.neig returns eigen vectors matrix N-M M symmetric n n matrix -sites neighbouring graph N diagonal matrix neighbour numbers. orthobasis.line returns analytical solution linear neighbouring graph. orthobasic.circ returns analytical solution circular neighbouring graph. orthobsic.mat returns eigen vectors general link matrix M. orthobasis.haar returns wavelet haar basis.

title: Orthonormal basis for orthonormal transform — orthobasis
code: orthobasis.neig(neig) orthobasis.line(n) orthobasis.circ(n) orthobasis.mat(mat, cnw=TRUE) orthobasis.haar(n) # S3 method for class 'orthobasis' print(x,..., nr = 6, nc = 4) # S3 method for class 'orthobasis' plot(x,...) # S3 method for class 'orthobasis' summary(object,...) is.orthobasis(x)

title: Orthonormal basis for orthonormal transform — orthobasis
text: neig object class neig n integer defines length vectors mat n n phylogenetic spatial link matrix cnw TRUE, matrix neighbouring graph modified give Constant Neighbouring Weights x, object object class orthobasis nr, nc number rows columns printed ... : arguments passed methods

title: Orthonormal basis for orthonormal transform — orthobasis
text: functions return object class orthobasis containing data frame. data frame defines orthonormal basis various attributes: names names vectors row.names row names data frame class class values optional associated eigenvalues weights weights rows call : call

title: Orthonormal basis for orthonormal transform — orthobasis
code: # a 2D spatial orthobasis w <- gridrowcol(8, 8) if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   g1 <- s.value(w$xy, w$orthobasis[, 1:16], pleg.drawKey = FALSE, pgri.text.cex = 0,      ylim = c(0, 10), porigin.include = FALSE, paxes.draw = FALSE)   g2 <- s1d.barchart(attr(w$orthobasis, "values"), p1d.horizontal = FALSE,      labels = names(attr(w$orthobasis, "values")), plabels.cex = 0.7)  } else {   par(mfrow = c(4, 4))   for(k in 1:16)     s.value(w$xy, w$orthobasis[, k], cleg = 0, csi = 2, incl = FALSE,       addax = FALSE, sub = k, csub = 4, ylim = c(0, 10), cgri = 0)   par(mfrow = c(1, 1))   barplot(attr(w$orthobasis, "values")) }     # Haar 1D orthobasis w <- orthobasis.haar(32) par(mfrow = c(8, 4)) par(mar = c(0.1, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1))  for (k in 1:31) {     plot(w[, k], type = "S", xlab = "", ylab = "", xaxt = "n",      yaxt = "n", xaxs = "i", yaxs = "i", ylim = c(-4.5, 4.5))     points(w[, k], type = "p", pch = 20, cex = 1.5) }  # a 1D orthobasis w <- orthobasis.line(n = 33) par(mfrow = c(8, 4))  par(mar = c(0.1, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1))  for (k in 1:32) {     plot(w[, k], type = "l", xlab = "", ylab = "", xaxt = "n",      yaxt = "n", xaxs = "i", yaxs = "i", ylim = c(-1.5, 1.5))     points(w[, k], type = "p", pch = 20, cex = 1.5) }   if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   s1d.barchart(attr(w, "values"), p1d.horizontal = FALSE, labels = names(attr(w, "values")),      plab.cex = 0.7) } else {   par(mfrow = c(1, 1))   barplot(attr(w, "values")) }   w <- orthobasis.circ(n = 26) #par(mfrow = c(5, 5)) #par(mar = c(0.1, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1)) # for (k in 1:25)  #    dotcircle(w[, k], xlim = c(-1.5, 1.5), cleg = 0)  par(mfrow = c(1, 1)) #barplot(attr(w, "values"))  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # a spatial orthobasis data(mafragh) w <- orthobasis.neig(neig2nb(mafragh$nb)) if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   s.value(mafragh$xy, w[, 1:8], plegend.drawKey = FALSE)   s1d.barchart(attr(w, "values"), p1d.horizontal = FALSE) } else {   par(mfrow = c(4, 2))   for(k in 1:8)     s.value(mafragh$xy, w[, k], cleg = 0, sub = as.character(k), csub = 3)   par(mfrow = c(1, 1))   barplot(attr(w, "values")) }  # a phylogenetic orthobasis data(njplot) phy <- newick2phylog(njplot$tre) wA <- phy$Ascores wW <- phy$Wscores table.phylog(phylog = phy, wA, clabel.row = 0, clabel.col  = 0.5) table.phylog(phylog = phy, wW, clabel.row = 0, clabel.col  = 0.5)  } # }

what: Principal component analysis with respect to instrumental variables — pcaiv
title: Principal component analysis with respect to instrumental variables — pcaiv
text: performs principal component analysis respect instrumental variables. includes redundancy analysis (RDA, dudi argument created dudi.pca) canonical correspondence analysis (CCA, dudi argument created dudi.coa) special cases.

title: Principal component analysis with respect to instrumental variables — pcaiv
code: pcaiv(dudi, df, scannf = TRUE, nf = 2) # S3 method for class 'pcaiv' plot(x, xax = 1, yax = 2, ...)  # S3 method for class 'pcaiv' print(x, ...) # S3 method for class 'pcaiv' summary(object, ...)

title: Principal component analysis with respect to instrumental variables — pcaiv
text: dudi duality diagram, object class dudi df data frame rows scannf logical value indicating whether eigenvalues bar plot displayed nf scannf FALSE, integer indicating number kept axes  x, object object class pcaiv xax column number x-axis yax column number y-axis ... arguments passed methods

title: Principal component analysis with respect to instrumental variables — pcaiv
text: returns object class pcaiv, sub-class class dudi tab data frame modified array (projected variables) cw numeric vector column weigths (dudi) lw numeric vector row weigths (dudi) eig vector eigenvalues rank integer indicating rank studied matrix nf integer indicating number kept axes c1 data frame Pseudo Principal Axes (PPA) li data frame predicted values X co data frame inner products CPC Y l1 data frame Constrained Principal Components (CPC) call matched call X data frame explanatory variables Y data frame dependant variables ls data frame projections lines dudi$tab PPA param table containing information contributions analyses : absolute (1) cumulative (2) contributions decomposition inertia dudi object, absolute (3) cumulative (4) variances projections, ration (5) cumulative variances projections (4) cumulative contributions (2), square coefficient correlation (6) eigenvalues pcaiv (7) data frame Principal axes dudi$tab PPA fa data frame loadings (Constraint Principal Components linear combinations X cor data frame correlations CPC X

title: Principal component analysis with respect to instrumental variables — pcaiv
text: Rao, C. R. (1964) use interpretation principal component analysis applied research. Sankhya, 26, 329–359. Obadia, J. (1978) L'analyse en composantes explicatives. Revue de Statistique Appliquee, 24, 5–28. Lebreton, J. D., Sabatier, R., Banco G.  Bacou . M. (1991) Principal component correspondence analyses respect instrumental variables : overview role studies structure-activity species- environment relationships. J. Devillers W. Karcher, editors. Applied Multivariate Analysis SAR Environmental Studies, Kluwer Academic Publishers, 85–114. Ter Braak, C. J. F. (1986) Canonical correspondence analysis : new eigenvector technique multivariate direct gradient analysis. Ecology, 67, 1167–1179. Ter Braak, C. J. F. (1987) analysis vegetation-environment relationships canonical correspondence analysis. Vegetatio, 69, 69–77. Chessel, D., Lebreton J. D. Yoccoz N. (1987) Propriétés de l'analyse canonique des correspondances. Une utilisation en hydrobiologie. Revue de Statistique Appliquée, 35, 55–72.

title: Principal component analysis with respect to instrumental variables — pcaiv
text: Daniel Chessel  Anne-Béatrice Dufour anne-beatrice.dufour@univ-lyon1.fr Stéphane Dray stephane.dray@univ-lyon1.fr

title: Principal component analysis with respect to instrumental variables — pcaiv
code: # example for the pcaiv data(rhone) pca1 <- dudi.pca(rhone$tab, scan = FALSE, nf = 3) iv1 <- pcaiv(pca1, rhone$disch, scan = FALSE) summary(iv1) #> Principal component analysis with instrumental variables #>  #> Class: pcaiv dudi #> Call: pcaiv(dudi = pca1, df = rhone$disch, scannf = FALSE) #>  #> Total inertia: 7.543 #>  #> Eigenvalues: #>     Ax1     Ax2     Ax3  #>  3.7031  3.5381  0.3015  #>  #> Projected inertia (%): #>     Ax1     Ax2     Ax3  #>  49.095  46.907   3.998  #>  #> Cumulative projected inertia (%): #>     Ax1   Ax1:2   Ax1:3  #>    49.1    96.0   100.0  #>  #> Total unconstrained inertia (pca1): 15 #>  #> Inertia of pca1 explained by rhone$disch (%): 50.28 #>  #> Decomposition per axis: #>   iner inercum inerC inercumC ratio    R2 lambda #> 1 6.27    6.27  5.52     5.52 0.879 0.671   3.70 #> 2 4.14   10.42  4.74    10.25 0.984 0.747   3.54 plot(iv1) #> Error in s.arrow(dfxy = na.omit(iv1$fa), xax = 1, yax = 2, plot = FALSE,     storeData = TRUE, pos = -3, psub = list(text = "X loadings"),     plabels = list(cex = 1.25)): non convenient selection for dfxy (can not be converted to dataframe)  # example for the caiv data(rpjdl) millog <- log(rpjdl$mil + 1) coa1 <- dudi.coa(rpjdl$fau, scann = FALSE) caiv1 <- pcaiv(coa1, millog, scan = FALSE)  if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   G1 <- plot(caiv1)      # analysis with c1 - as - li -ls   # projections of inertia axes on PCAIV axes   G2 <- s.corcircle(caiv1$as)      # Species positions   g31 <- s.label(caiv1$c1, xax = 2, yax = 1, plab.cex = 0.5, xlim = c(-4, 4), plot = FALSE)   # Sites positions at the weighted mean of present species   g32 <- s.label(caiv1$ls, xax = 2, yax = 1, plab.cex = 0, plot = FALSE)   G3 <- superpose(g31, g32, plot = TRUE)      # Prediction of the positions by regression on environmental variables   G4 <- s.match(caiv1$ls, caiv1$li, xax = 2, yax = 1, plab.cex = 0.5)      # analysis with fa - l1 - co -cor   # canonical weights giving unit variance combinations   G5 <- s.arrow(caiv1$fa)      # sites position by environmental variables combinations   # position of species by averaging   g61 <- s.label(caiv1$l1, xax = 2, yax = 1, plab.cex = 0, ppoi.cex = 1.5, plot = FALSE)   g62 <- s.label(caiv1$co, xax = 2, yax = 1, plot = FALSE)   G6 <- superpose(g61, g62, plot = TRUE)      G7 <- s.distri(caiv1$l1, rpjdl$fau, xax = 2, yax = 1, ellipseSize = 0, starSize = 0.33)      # coherence between weights and correlations   g81 <- s.corcircle(caiv1$cor, xax = 2, yax = 1, plot = FALSE)   g82 <- s.arrow(caiv1$fa, xax = 2, yax = 1, plot = FALSE)   G8 <- cbindADEg(g81, g82, plot = TRUE)  } else {   plot(caiv1)      # analysis with c1 - as - li -ls   # projections of inertia axes on PCAIV axes   s.corcircle(caiv1$as)      # Species positions   s.label(caiv1$c1, 2, 1, clab = 0.5, xlim = c(-4, 4))   # Sites positions at the weighted mean of present species   s.label(caiv1$ls, 2, 1, clab = 0, cpoi = 1, add.p = TRUE)      # Prediction of the positions by regression on environmental variables   s.match(caiv1$ls, caiv1$li, 2, 1, clab = 0.5)      # analysis with fa - l1 - co -cor   # canonical weights giving unit variance combinations   s.arrow(caiv1$fa)      # sites position by environmental variables combinations   # position of species by averaging   s.label(caiv1$l1, 2, 1, clab = 0, cpoi = 1.5)   s.label(caiv1$co, 2, 1, add.plot = TRUE)      s.distri(caiv1$l1, rpjdl$fau, 2, 1, cell = 0, csta = 0.33)   s.label(caiv1$co, 2, 1, clab = 0.75, add.plot = TRUE)      # coherence between weights and correlations   par(mfrow = c(1, 2))   s.corcircle(caiv1$cor, 2, 1)   s.arrow(caiv1$fa, 2, 1)   par(mfrow = c(1, 1)) } #> Error in s.arrow(dfxy = na.omit(caiv1$fa), xax = 1, yax = 2, plot = FALSE,     storeData = TRUE, pos = -3, psub = list(text = "X loadings"),     plabels = list(cex = 1.25)): non convenient selection for dfxy (can not be converted to dataframe)

title: Principal Component Analysis with respect to orthogonal instrumental variables — pcaivortho
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data(avimedi) cla <- avimedi$plan$reg:avimedi$plan$str # simple ordination coa1 <- dudi.coa(avimedi$fau, scan = FALSE, nf = 3) # within region w1 <- wca(coa1, avimedi$plan$reg, scan = FALSE) # no region the same result pcaivnonA <- pcaivortho(coa1, avimedi$plan$reg, scan = FALSE) summary(pcaivnonA) # region + strate interAplusB <- pcaiv(coa1, avimedi$plan, scan = FALSE)  if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   g1 <- s.class(coa1$li, cla, psub.text = "Sans contrainte", plot = FALSE)   g21 <- s.match(w1$li, w1$ls, plab.cex = 0, psub.text = "Intra Région", plot = FALSE)   g22 <- s.class(w1$li, cla, plot = FALSE)   g2 <- superpose(g21, g22)   g31 <- s.match(pcaivnonA$li, pcaivnonA$ls, plab.cex = 0, psub.tex = "Contrainte Non A",      plot = FALSE)   g32 <- s.class(pcaivnonA$li, cla, plot = FALSE)   g3 <- superpose(g31, g32)   g41 <- s.match(interAplusB$li, interAplusB$ls, plab.cex = 0, psub.text = "Contrainte A + B",      plot = FALSE)   g42 <- s.class(interAplusB$li, cla, plot = FALSE)   g4 <- superpose(g41, g42)   G <- ADEgS(list(g1, g2, g3, g4), layout = c(2, 2))  } else {   par(mfrow = c(2, 2))   s.class(coa1$li, cla, sub = "Sans contrainte")   s.match(w1$li, w1$ls, clab = 0, sub = "Intra Région")   s.class(w1$li, cla, add.plot = TRUE)   s.match(pcaivnonA$li, pcaivnonA$ls, clab = 0, sub = "Contrainte Non A")   s.class(pcaivnonA$li, cla, add.plot = TRUE)   s.match(interAplusB$li, interAplusB$ls, clab = 0, sub = "Contrainte A + B")   s.class(interAplusB$li, cla, add.plot = TRUE)   par(mfrow = c(1,1)) }} # }

title: Phylogeny — phylog
text: Create use objects class phylog. phylog.extract returns objects class phylog. extracts sub-trees tree. phylog.permut returns objects class phylog. creates different representations compatible tree topology.

title: Phylogeny — phylog
code: # S3 method for class 'phylog' print(x, ...) phylog.extract(phylog, node, distance = TRUE) phylog.permut(phylog, list.nodes = NULL, distance = TRUE)

title: Phylogeny — phylog
text: x, phylog : object class phylog ... : arguments passed methods node : string characters giving node name. functions extracts tree rooted node. distance : TRUE, functions retain branch lengths. FALSE, returns tree arbitrary branch lengths (branch length equals one) list.nodes : list elements vectors string character corresponding direct descendants nodes. list defines one representation compatible tree topology among set possibilities.

title: Phylogeny — phylog
text: Returns list class phylog : tre : character string phylogenetic tree Newick format whithout branch length values leaves : vector names corresponds leaves values gives distance leaves nodes closest leaves nodes : vector names corresponds nodes values gives distance nodes nodes closest leaves parts : list elements gives direct descendants nodes paths : list elements gives path leading root taxonomic units (leaves nodes) droot : vector names corresponds taxonomic units values gives distance taxonomic units root call : call Wmat : phylogenetic link matrix, generally called covariance matrix. Matrix values \(Wmat_{ij}\) correspond path length lead root first common ancestor two leaves j Wdist : phylogenetic distance matrix class 'dist'. Matrix values \(Wdist_{ij}\) correspond \(\sqrt{d_{ij}}\) \(d_{ij}\) classical distance two leaves j Wvalues : vector eigen values Wmat Wscores : data frame eigen vectors Wmat. data frame defines orthobasis used calculate orthonormal decomposition biological trait tree. Amat : phylogenetic link matrix stemed Abouheif's test defined Ollier et al. (submited) Avalues : vector eigen values Amat Adim : number positive eigen values Ascores : data frame eigen vectors Amat. data frame defines orthobasis used calculate orthonormal decomposition biological trait tree. Aparam : data frame attributes associated nodes. Bindica : data frame giving taxonomic units partition leaves associated Bscores : data frame giving orthobasis defined Ollier et al. (submited) used calculate orthonormal decomposition biological trait tree. Bvalues : vector giving degree phylogenetic autocorrelation vectors Bscores (Moran's form calculated matrix Wmat) Blabels : vector giving nodes name vector Bscores associated

title: Phylogeny — phylog
text: Ollier, S., Couteron, P. Chessel, D. (2006) Orthonormal transform decompose variance life-history trait across phylogenetic tree. Biometrics Biometrics, 62, 2, 471–477.

title: Phylogeny — phylog
text: Daniel Chessel   Sébastien Ollier sebastien.ollier@u-psud.fr

title: Phylogeny — phylog
code: marthans.tre <- NULL marthans.tre[1] <-"((((1:4,2:4)a:5,(3:7,4:7)b:2)c:2,5:11)d:2," marthans.tre[2] <- "((6:5,7:5)e:4,(8:4,9:4)f:5)g:4);" marthans.phylog <- newick2phylog(marthans.tre) marthans.phylog #> Phylogenetic tree with 9 leaves and 8 nodes #> $class: phylog #> $call: newick2phylog(x.tre = marthans.tre) #> $tre: ((((X1,X2)a,(X3,X4)b)c,X5...,((X6,X7)e,(X8,X9)f)g)Root;  #>  #>         class   length content                                      #> $leaves numeric 9      length of the first preceeding adjacent edge #> $nodes  numeric 8      length of the first preceeding adjacent edge #> $parts  list    8      subsets of descendant nodes                  #> $paths  list    17     path from root to node or leave              #> $droot  numeric 17     distance to root                             #>  #>          class      dim content                                    #> $Wmat    matrix     9-9 W matrix : root to the closest ancestor    #> $Wdist   dist       36  Nodal distances                            #> $Wvalues numeric    8   Eigen values of QWQ/sum(Q)                 #> $Wscores data.frame 9-8 Eigen vectors of QWQ '1/n' normed          #> $Amat    matrix     9-9 Topological proximity matrix A             #> $Avalues numeric    8   Eigen values of QAQ matrix                 #> $Adim    integer    1   number of positive eigen values of QAQ     #> $Ascores data.frame 9-8 Eigen vectors of QAQ '1/n' normed          #> $Aparam  data.frame 8-3 Topological indices for nodes              #> $Bindica data.frame 9-8 class indicator from nodes                 #> $Bscores data.frame 9-8 Topological orthonormal basis '1/n' normed #> $Blabels character  8   Nodes labelling from orthonormal basis      if(requireNamespace("ape", quietly = TRUE)) {   marthans.phylo <- ape::read.tree(text = marthans.tre)   marthans.phylo    par(mfrow = c(1, 2))   plot(marthans.phylog, cnode = 3, f = 0.8, cle = 3)   plot(marthans.phylo)   par(mfrow = c(1, 1)) }

title: Between-Class Analysis — between
code: data(meaudret)  pca1 <- dudi.pca(meaudret$env, scan = FALSE, nf = 4) pca2 <- dudi.pca(meaudret$spe, scal = FALSE, scan = FALSE, nf = 4) bet1 <- bca(pca1, meaudret$design$site, scan = FALSE, nf = 2) bet2 <- bca(pca2, meaudret$design$site, scan = FALSE, nf = 2)  if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   g1 <- s.class(pca1$li, meaudret$design$site, psub.text = "Principal Component Analysis (env)",      plot = FALSE)   g2 <- s.class(pca2$li, meaudret$design$site, psub.text = "Principal Component Analysis (spe)",      plot = FALSE)   g3 <- s.class(bet1$ls, meaudret$design$site, psub.text = "Between sites PCA (env)",      plot = FALSE)   g4 <- s.class(bet2$ls, meaudret$design$site, psub.text = "Between sites PCA (spe)",      plot = FALSE)   G <- ADEgS(list(g1, g2, g3, g4), layout = c(2, 2))    } else {   par(mfrow = c(2, 2))   s.class(pca1$li, meaudret$design$site, sub = "Principal Component Analysis (env)", csub = 1.75)   s.class(pca2$li, meaudret$design$site, sub = "Principal Component Analysis (spe)", csub = 1.75)   s.class(bet1$ls, meaudret$design$site, sub = "Between sites PCA (env)", csub = 1.75)   s.class(bet2$ls, meaudret$design$site, sub = "Between sites PCA (spe)", csub = 1.75)   par(mfrow = c(1,1)) }   coib <- coinertia(bet1, bet2, scann = FALSE) plot(coib) #> Error in s.corcircle(dfxy = coib$aX, xax = 1, yax = 2, plot = FALSE, storeData = TRUE,     pos = -3, psub = list(text = "Unconstrained axes (X)"), pbackground = list(        box = FALSE), plabels = list(cex = 1.25)): non convenient selection for dfxy (can not be converted to dataframe)

title: Plot phylogenies — plot.phylog

title: Plot phylogenies — plot.phylog
code: # S3 method for class 'phylog' plot(x, y = NULL, f.phylog = 0.5, cleaves = 1, cnodes = 0,  labels.leaves = names(x$leaves), clabel.leaves = 1,  labels.nodes = names(x$nodes), clabel.nodes = 0, sub = "",  csub = 1.25, possub = "bottomleft", draw.box = FALSE, ...) radial.phylog(phylog, circle = 1, cleaves = 1, cnodes = 0,  labels.leaves = names(phylog$leaves), clabel.leaves = 1,  labels.nodes = names(phylog$nodes), clabel.nodes = 0,  draw.box = FALSE) enum.phylog(phylog, no.over = 1000)

title: Plot phylogenies — plot.phylog
text: x, phylog object class phylog y vector values correspond leaves positions f.phylog size coefficient tree size (parameter draw tree proportion leaves label) circle size coefficient outer circle cleaves character size plotting points represent leaves, used par("cex")*cleaves. zero, points drawn cnodes character size plotting points represent nodes, used par("cex")*cnodes. zero, points drawn labels.leaves vector strings characters leaves labels clabel.leaves character size leaves labels, used par("cex")*clabel.leaves. zero, leaves labels drawn labels.nodes vector strings characters nodes labels clabel.nodes character size nodes labels, used par("cex")*clabel.nodes. zero, nodes labels drawn sub string characters inserted legend csub character size legend, used par("cex")*csub possub string characters indicating sub-title position ("topleft", "topright", "bottomleft", "bottomright") draw.box TRUE draws box around current plot function box() ... arguments passed methods .size coefficient number representations

title: Plot phylogenies — plot.phylog

title: Plot phylogenies — plot.phylog
text: function enum.phylog returns matrix many columns leaves. row gives permutation set leaves {1,2,...,f} compatible phylogeny's topology.

title: Plot phylogenies — plot.phylog
text: Daniel Chessel   Sébastien Ollier sebastien.ollier@u-psud.fr

title: Plot phylogenies — plot.phylog
code: data(newick.eg) par(mfrow = c(3,2)) for(i in 1:6) plot(newick2phylog(newick.eg[[i]], FALSE),  clea = 2, clabel.l = 3, cnod = 2.5)  par(mfrow = c(1,1))  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ par(mfrow = c(1,2)) plot(newick2phylog(newick.eg[[11]], FALSE), clea = 1.5,  clabel.l = 1.5, clabel.nod = 0.75, f = 0.8) plot(newick2phylog(newick.eg[[10]], FALSE), clabel.l = 0,  clea = 0, cn = 0, f = 1) par(mfrow = c(1,1)) } # }  par(mfrow = c(2,2)) w7 <- newick2phylog("(((((1,2,3)b),(6)c),(4,5)d,7)f);") plot(w7,clabel.l = 1.5, clabel.n = 1.5, f = 0.8, cle = 2,  cnod = 3, sub = "(((((1,2,3)b),(6)c),(4,5)d,7)f);", csub = 2) w <- NULL w[1] <- "((((e1:4,e2:4)a:5,(e3:7,e4:7)b:2)c:2,e5:11)d:2," w[2] <- "((e6:5,e7:5)e:4,(e8:4,e9:4)f:5)g:4);" plot(newick2phylog(w), f = 0.8, cnod = 2, cleav = 2, clabel.l = 2)  data(taxo.eg) w <- taxo2phylog(as.taxo(taxo.eg[[1]])) plot(w, clabel.lea = 1.25, clabel.n = 1.25, sub = "Taxonomy",  csub = 3, f = 0.8, possub = "topleft")  provi.tre <- "(((a,b,c,d,e)A,(f,g,h)B)C)D;" provi.phy <- newick2phylog(provi.tre) plot(provi.phy, clabel.l = 2, clabel.n = 2, f = 0.8)  par(mfrow = c(1,1))  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ par(mfrow = c(3,3)) for (j in 1:6) radial.phylog(newick2phylog(newick.eg[[j]],  FALSE), clabel.l = 2, cnodes = 2) radial.phylog(newick2phylog(newick.eg[[7]],FALSE), clabel.l = 2) radial.phylog(newick2phylog(newick.eg[[8]],FALSE), clabel.l = 0,  circle = 1.8) radial.phylog(newick2phylog(newick.eg[[9]],FALSE), clabel.l = 1,  clabel.n = 1, cle = 0, cnode = 1) par(mfrow = c(1,1))  data(bsetal97) bsetal.phy = taxo2phylog(as.taxo(bsetal97$taxo[,1:3]), FALSE) radial.phylog(bsetal.phy, cnod = 1, clea = 1, clabel.l = 0.75,  draw.box = TRUE, cir = 1.1) par(mfrow = c(1,1)) } # }  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # plot all the possible representations of a phylogenetic tree a <- "((a,b)A,(c,d,(e,f)B)C)D;" wa <- newick2phylog(a) wx <- enum.phylog(wa) dim(wx)  par(mfrow = c(6,8)) fun <- function(x) {     w  <-NULL     lapply(x, function(y) w<<-paste(w,as.character(y),sep=""))     plot(wa, x, clabel.n = 1.25, f = 0.75, clabel.l = 2,      box = FALSE, cle = 1.5, sub = w, csub = 2)     invisible()} apply(wx,1,fun) par(mfrow = c(1,1)) } # }

what: Phylogeny and quantitative traits of birds — procella
title: Phylogeny and quantitative traits of birds — procella

title: Phylogeny and quantitative traits of birds — procella
code: data(procella)

title: Phylogeny and quantitative traits of birds — procella
text: procella list containing 2 following objects: tre character string giving phylogenetic tree Newick format. traits data frame 19 species 6 traits

title: Phylogeny and quantitative traits of birds — procella
text: Variables procella$traits following ones:  site.fid: numeric vector describes percentage site fidelity mate.fid: numeric vector describes percentage mate fidelity mass: integer vector describes adult body weight (g) ALE: numeric vector describes adult life expectancy (years) BF: numeric vector describes breeding frequencies col.size: integer vector describes colony size (nests monitored)

title: Phylogeny and quantitative traits of birds — procella
text: Bried, J., Pontier, D. Jouventin, P. (2002) Mate fidelity monogamus birds: re-examination Procellariiformes. Animal Behaviour, 65, 235–246. See data description http://pbil.univ-lyon1.fr/R/pdf/pps037.pdf (French).

title: Phylogeny and quantitative traits of birds — procella
code: data(procella) pro.phy <- newick2phylog(procella$tre) plot(pro.phy,clabel.n = 1, clabel.l = 1)  wt <- procella$traits wt$site.fid[is.na(wt$site.fid)] <- mean(wt$site.fid[!is.na(wt$site.fid)]) wt$site.fid <- asin(sqrt(wt$site.fid/100)) wt$ALE[is.na(wt$ALE)] <- mean(wt$ALE[!is.na(wt$ALE)]) wt$ALE <- sqrt(wt$ALE) wt$BF[is.na(wt$BF)] <- mean(wt$BF[!is.na(wt$BF)]) wt$mass <- log(wt$mass) wt <- wt[, -6] table.phylog(scalewt(wt), pro.phy, csi = 2)  gearymoran(pro.phy$Amat,wt,9999) #> class: krandtest lightkrandtest  #> Monte-Carlo tests #> Call: as.krandtest(sim = matrix(res$result, ncol = nvar, byrow = TRUE),  #>     obs = res$obs, alter = alter, names = test.names) #>  #> Number of tests:   5  #>  #> Adjustment method for multiple comparisons:   none  #> Permutation number:   9999  #>       Test          Obs      Std.Obs   Alter Pvalue #> 1 site.fid 0.0999203829  0.741020383 greater 0.2193 #> 2 mate.fid 0.1775615101  1.237425240 greater 0.1157 #> 3     mass 0.5446640572  3.866273406 greater 0.0002 #> 4      ALE 0.0009167618 -0.005105059 greater 0.4721 #> 5       BF 0.1972100051  1.411421375 greater 0.0872 #>

title: Simple Procruste Rotation between two sets of points — procuste
code: data(macaca) pro1 <- procuste(macaca$xy1, macaca$xy2, scal = FALSE) pro2 <- procuste(macaca$xy1, macaca$xy2) if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   g1 <- s.match(pro1$tabX, pro1$rotY, plab.cex = 0.7, plot = FALSE)   g2 <- s.match(pro1$tabY, pro1$rotX, plab.cex = 0.7, plot = FALSE)   g3 <- s.match(pro2$tabX, pro2$rotY, plab.cex = 0.7, plot = FALSE)   g4 <- s.match(pro2$tabY, pro2$rotX, plab.cex = 0.7, plot = FALSE)   G <- ADEgS(list(g1, g2, g3, g4), layout = c(2, 2)) } else {   par(mfrow = c(2, 2))   s.match(pro1$tabX, pro1$rotY, clab = 0.7)   s.match(pro1$tabY, pro1$rotX, clab = 0.7)   s.match(pro2$tabX, pro2$rotY, clab = 0.7)   s.match(pro2$tabY, pro2$rotX, clab = 0.7)   par(mfrow = c(1,1)) }   data(doubs) pca1 <- dudi.pca(doubs$env, scal = TRUE, scann = FALSE) pca2 <- dudi.pca(doubs$fish, scal = FALSE, scann = FALSE) pro3 <- procuste(pca1$tab, pca2$tab, nf = 2) if(adegraphicsLoaded()) {   g11 <- s.traject(pro3$scorX, plab.cex = 0, plot = FALSE)   g12 <- s.label(pro3$scorX, plab.cex = 0.8, plot = FALSE)   g1 <- superpose(g11, g12)   g21 <- s.traject(pro3$scorY, plab.cex = 0, plot = FALSE)   g22 <- s.label(pro3$scorY, plab.cex = 0.8, plot = FALSE)   g2 <- superpose(g21, g22)   g3 <- s.arrow(pro3$loadX, plab.cex = 0.75, plot = FALSE)   g4 <- s.arrow(pro3$loadY, plab.cex = 0.75, plot = FALSE)   G <- ADEgS(list(g1, g2, g3, g4), layout = c(2, 2))  } else {   par(mfrow = c(2, 2))   s.traject(pro3$scorX, clab = 0)   s.label(pro3$scorX, clab = 0.8, add.p = TRUE)   s.traject(pro3$scorY, clab = 0)   s.label(pro3$scorY, clab = 0.8, add.p = TRUE)   s.arrow(pro3$loadX, clab = 0.75)   s.arrow(pro3$loadY, clab = 0.75)   par(mfrow = c(1, 1)) }   plot(pro3) #> Error in s.arrow(dfxy = pro3$loadX, xax = 1, yax = 2, plot = FALSE, storeData = TRUE,     pos = -3, psub = list(text = "X loadings"), plabels = list(        cex = 1.25)): non convenient selection for dfxy (can not be converted to dataframe) randtest(pro3) #> Monte-Carlo test #> Call: procuste.randtest(df1 = df1, df2 = df2, nrepet = nrepet) #>  #> Observation: 0.6562  #>  #> Based on 999 replicates #> Simulated p-value: 0.001  #> Alternative hypothesis: greater  #>  #>     Std.Obs Expectation    Variance  #> 6.746043740 0.342170480 0.002166918   data(fruits) plot(procuste(scalewt(fruits$jug), scalewt(fruits$var)))

title: Permutation test for double principal coordinate analysis (DPCoA) — randtest.dpcoa
text: Model 1p permutes names columns abundance matrix. Model 1s permutes abundances categories (columns abundance matrix, usually species) within collections (rows abundance matrix, usually communities). categories positive abundances permuted. null models introduced Hardy (2008). null model can used entering name function. example, loading picante package R, model=randomizeMatrix, permutations follow function randomizeMatrix available picante. function can used provided returns abundance matrix similar size observed abundance matrix. Parameters chosen function can added randtest.dpcoa. example, using parameter null.model randomizeMatrix, following command can used: randtest.dpcoa(xtest, model = randomizeMatrix, null.model = "trialswap")

title: Class of the Permutation Tests (in C). — randtest
text: .randtest returns list class randtest.plot.randtest draws simulated values histograms position observed value.

title: Class of the Permutation Tests (in C). — randtest
text: alternative hypothesis "greater", p-value estimated : (number random values equal greater observed one + 1)/(number permutations + 1). null hypothesis rejected p-value less significance level. alternative hypothesis "less", p-value estimated : (number random values equal less observed one + 1)/(number permutations + 1). , null hypothesis rejected p-value less significance level. Lastly, alternative hypothesis "two-sided", estimation p-value equivalent one used "greater" except random observed values firstly centered (using average random values) secondly transformed absolute values. Note suitable symmetric random distribution.

title: Class of the Permutation Tests (in C). — randtest

what: Genetic structure of two nitrogen fixing bacteria influenced by geographical isolation and host specialization — rhizobium
title: Genetic structure of two nitrogen fixing bacteria influenced by geographical isolation and host specialization — rhizobium
text: data set concerns fixing bacteria belonging genus Sinorhizobium (Rhizobiaceae) associated plant genus Medicago (Fabaceae). combination two data sets fully available online GenBank published two recent papers (see reference ). complete sampling procedure described Additional file 3 reference . delineated six populations according geographical origin (France: F, Tunisia Hadjeb: TH, Tunisia Enfidha: TE), host plant (M. truncatula similar symbiotic specificity: T, M. laciniata: L), taxonomical status bacteria (S. meliloti: mlt, S. medicae: mdc). population called hereafter according three criteria, e.g. THLmlt population sampled Tunisia Hadjeb M. laciniata nodules include S. meliloti isolates. S. medicae interacts M. truncatula S. meliloti interacts M. laciniata (S. meliloti bv. medicaginis) M. truncatula (S. meliloti bv. meliloti). numbers individuals respectively 46 FTmdc, 43 FTmlt, 20 TETmdc, 24 TETmlt, 20 TELmlt, 42 THTmlt 20 THLmlt. Four different intergenic spacers (IGS), IGSNOD, IGSEXO, IGSGAB, IGSRKP, distributed different replication units model strain 1021 S. meliloti bv. meliloti sequenced characterize bacterial isolate (DNA extraction sequencing procedures described additional file). noteworthy IGSNOD marker located within nod gene cluster specific alleles loci determine ability S. meliloti strains interact either M. laciniata M. truncatula.
